citations.narrative:
The single turkey does not have a public barriers.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals
and the public.
Public barriers must be put in place to protect the animals and the public from injury.
To be corrected by March 8, 2024

The primary enclosure housing a single arctic fox does not have a six foot perimeter fence surrounding the primary
enclosure.
All outdoor housing facilities (i.e., facilities not entirely indoors) must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient
height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. Fences less than 6 feet high for wild or exotic animals must be
approved in writing by the Administrator. The fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by
restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the
facility, and so that it can function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient
distance from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and
animals or persons outside the perimeter fence. Such fences less than 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure must
be approved in writing by the Administrator.
A perimeter fence must be put in place no less that six foot in height and no less than three feet from the primary
enclosure, or a perimeter fence variance may be requested.
To be corrected by March 25, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
The single turkey does not have a public barriers. 
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with 
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals 
and the public. 
Public barriers must be put in place to protect the animals and the public from injury. 
To be corrected by March 8, 2024 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The primary enclosure housing a single arctic fox does not have a six foot perimeter fence surrounding the primary 
enclosure. 
All outdoor housing facilities (i.e., facilities not entirely indoors) must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient 
height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. Fences less than 6 feet high for wild or exotic animals must be 
approved in writing by the Administrator. The fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by 
restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the 
facility, and so that it can function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient 
distance from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and 
animals or persons outside the perimeter fence. Such fences less than 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure must 
be approved in writing by the Administrator. 
A perimeter fence must be put in place no less that six foot in height and no less than three feet from the primary 
enclosure, or a perimeter fence variance may be requested. 
To be corrected by March 25, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
